title: Are the scientists lying about COVID-19? - Quora

response.answer_text: Whenever you hear a conspiracy theory, then always ask yourselves two questions: What would the conspirators gain from the conspiracy? Bear in mind that the potential gains to the conspirators must significantly outweigh the risks, or there is no point going ahead with the conspiracy.How many people would have to be in on the conspiracy for it to be successful? Conspiracies are most likely to remain secret when there are few people involved, and when the conspirators are a homogeneous group with a strong sense of belonging to the group.Scientists are generally truthful people. OK, over the years there have been a few who have been guilty of scientific fraud to further their career, but the nature of science is that it is self-correcting, and when other scientists fail to replicate the falsified results they tend to get found out, and get sacked. Lying is not a good way to progress in science in the medium- to long-term. So what would be the benefit of lying to the scientists that is sufficiently big to overcome the risk to their reputations and careers? For a conspiracy concerning a hot research topic like SARS-CoV-2, a conspiracy would have to include tens of thousands (at least) of scientists around the world. But remember that many scientists are independent thinkers, or they wouldn’t be particularly good at science. And the scientists working on this coronavirus live and work in diverse political systems. Any coronavirus conspiracy would be unmasked almost as soon as it was formed. So my answer is to ask yourself these two questions and see what you think.

Are the scientists lying about covid? Yes. Some of them, anyway… There are two groups involved here, both with some form of scientific credential. First is the much larger group of academics who are warning of how dangerous the virus is, and the overwhelming need to socially distance, wear masks, etc. Those with a PhD specifically in virology, epidemiology, etc will mostly be found in this group and they'll very much still be actively publishing research papers in the field. Second is the smaller group who have some form of political afilliation, to lobby groups, senators, the White House, etc. Most of them will have studied a science at best loosely related to epidemiology and are no longer involved in research. Their careers are often linked to various patrons and what they say publicly. This group is saying that the virus isn't much worse than flu, that it'll go away soon, and anything else that helps the economy and avoids panic prior to the presidential election. Both of these groups can arguably be called “scientists” to some greater or lesser degree, and they're saying opposing things. Therefore, yes, there must be people who call themselves scientists who are lying. I'll leave it as an exercise to the reader to determine which group it is, and whether or not they should still be entitled to continue calling themselves by that title.

Given the breadth of the question, no. There are a few million scientists; it wouldn’t be reasonable to believe that they: 1) could coordinate a falsehood, 2) agree to reiterate the falsehood, 3) fabricate the supporting evidence to sell the falsehood. Doubly so since their professional career is predicated on accuracy and precision, and being in the rare position where you discover something surprising and support it (as debunking a lie would be) is as close as a scientist will get to fame and fortune. Also, scientists produce a lot of information about COVID-19. It is clear that quite a bit is truthful because a lot is used for guidance for public health and medical treatment, and it works. Growth predictions are validated by public health numbers, etc. So, if there is a falsehood, it’s hidden in a lot of accurate and verifiable science. If we presume that not all scientists are lying, and we observe that not all things they say are lies, then we can say that “scientists” are not “lying about COVID”.

Scientists are trained to report objectively. This does not mean that scientists cannot make mistake. Part of the scientific methods is to rectify mistakes once they are discovered. Therefore, a scientific report is supposed to be the most reliable statement based on what could be found and known at the time. The case of covid is not an exception. In order not to tell lies, scientists are known to use ‘selective reporting’. They only report results that are advantageous to them; adverse findings are omitted. It is impossible to keep a report completely objective. Subjective elements are always there in every scientific report. Scientists need to admit such a shortcoming in order not to be labelled as lying. Scientists are also human and under immense pressure to produce results, especially in the case of covid. Are some of them lying purposely? It is not easy to know.
